Authors:
Oriol Lapiedra, Daniel Sol, Salvador Carranza, Jeremy
Michael Beaulieu
Title:
Behavioural changes and the adaptive diversification of
pigeons and doves
Journal:
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London, Biological
Sciences
Keywords:
evolutionary rates , behavioural drive, Bogert effect,
Columbiformes, evolutionary diversification, Ornstein-Uhlenbeck
Abstract:
A major question in evolutionary biology is what
determines the extent of evolutionary diversification. Behavioural
changes have long been suggested to be a major driver of phenotypic
diversification by exposing animals to new selective pressures.
Nevertheless, the role of behaviour in evolution remains controversial
because behavioural changes can also retard evolutionary change by
hiding genetic variation from selection. In the present study, we apply
recently implemented Ornstein-Uhlenbeck evolutionary models to show that
changes in foraging behaviour have brought associated evolutionary
responses in functionally relevant morphological traits of pigeons and
doves (Columbiformes). Specifically, arboreal-dwelling species have
evolved shorter tarsi and longer tails after a shift from a terrestrial
foraging behaviour, consistent with eco-morphological predictions.
Interestingly, the transition to arboreality accelerated the rates of
evolutionary divergence, leading to an increased morphological
specialization that may subsequently constrain reversals to terrestrial
foraging. Altogether, our results support the view that behaviour may
drive evolutionary diversification but they also highlight that the
evolutionary consequences largely depend on the ecological context and
the existence of morphological constraints.
